title: Quiz 1: Normal Pregnancy & Antenatal Care
description: Assessment of physiological changes during pregnancy, diagnosis, and Focused Antenatal Care (FANC) protocols.

questions.question: Match the obstetric terminology with its correct definition:

pairs.right: Total number of pregnancies regardless of outcome
Number of births after age of viability (28 weeks)
A woman who has never been pregnant
A woman pregnant more than one time

questions.explanation: Gravidity refers to the number of times a woman has been pregnant. Parity refers to births after viability. Nulligravida is never pregnant, and Multigravida is multiple pregnancies.
questions.hint: Think about the root words 'nulli' (none) and 'multi' (many).

questions.question: Which of the following is considered a POSITIVE (Confirmatory) sign of pregnancy?
questions.explanation: Positive signs confirm pregnancy indisputably: fetal heart sounds, palpable/visible fetal movements, and visualization via ultrasound. Morning sickness is presumptive; a test is probable.
questions.hint: Which sign cannot be caused by any other condition (like a tumor or hormonal imbalance)?

questions.question: During pregnancy, cardiac output decreases by approximately 40% due to the demand of the fetus.
questions.explanation: Cardiac output INCREASES by approximately 40% during pregnancy, reaching maximum at 20-24 weeks to meet metabolic needs.
questions.hint: Does the heart work harder or less during pregnancy?

questions.question: What is the specific term for the 'mask of pregnancy' or hyperpigmentation on the face (forehead/cheeks) during gestation?
questions.explanation: Chloasma is the hyperpigmentation of the face due to increased melanocyte-stimulating hormone.

questions.question: Identify the physiological changes in the Respiratory System during pregnancy. (Select all that apply)

options.text: Capillary dilatation in the respiratory tract causing nasal stuffiness

questions.explanation: Tidal volume increases, but residual volume DECREASES by 20%. The diaphragm rises, and capillary dilation is common.
questions.hint: Think about how deep the mother breathes and the physical space the uterus occupies.

questions.question: Arrange the standard Focused Antenatal Care (FANC) visit schedule in the correct chronological order:
questions.explanation: The standard FANC schedule is: <16 weeks, 16-28 weeks, 28-32 weeks, and 32-40 weeks.

questions.question: Review the Tetanus Toxoid (TT) schedule below. When should the **second** dose (TT2) be administered?

richContent.content:
DoseTiming
TT1At first contact
TT2?

questions.explanation: TT2 is given at least 4 weeks after TT1 to ensure antibody production.
questions.hint: It takes about a month for the immune system to be ready for the second dose.

questions.question: Using Naegeleâ€™s Rule, if a woman's LMP was 12th January 2020, her EDD would be calculated by adding ___BLANK___ days to the date and 9 months to the month.
questions.explanation: Naegele's rule involves adding 7 days to the first day of the LMP and adding 9 months (or subtracting 3 months).
questions.hint: How many days are in a week?

questions.question: Which of the following are DANGER SIGNS during pregnancy that require immediate attention? (Select all that apply)
questions.explanation: Danger signs include vaginal bleeding, severe headache/blurred vision (preeclampsia), and reduced fetal movement. Frequency and mild backache are common minor disorders.
questions.hint: Select symptoms that could threaten life or indicate severe pathology.

questions.question: Supine Hypotension Syndrome is caused by the heavy uterus compressing the aorta when the mother lies on her back.
questions.explanation: It is caused by compression of the **Inferior Vena Cava**, not the aorta, reducing venous return to the heart.
questions.hint: Which major vessel carries blood back to the heart?
